Title: Belief congruence
Content: Belief congruence was first proposed by Milton Rokeach in 1960. Belief is more important than ethnic or racial membership as a determinant of social discrimination. Similar beliefs promote liking and social harmony among people while dissimilar beliefs produce dislike and prejudice. The principle states that we value beliefs and people based on how closely they align with our own beliefs. This principle was further elaborated by himself later in 1965 that belief system is a crucial alignment point for individuals. prejudice arises from how people react to differences or lack of congruence in belief systems. Rokeach and his colleagues designed an experiment to separate the effects of group membership from belief congruence on individuals preferences. Participants rated their liking for people who were either part of their own group or a different one and who had beliefs that were either similar or dissimilar to them. Study found shared beliefs were a stronger predictor of liking than simply belonging to the same group. This was illustrated by instances where white participants preferred a black individual with similar beliefs over a white individual with differing beliefs. Race was found more important than belief when it comes to more intimate relationships such as friendship. Critiques argue that belief congruence primarily addresses discrimination in contexts of small social distance. Theorys applicability to scenarios involving larger social distances such as neighbourhood or university settings where prejudice and discrimination might manifest differently remains questioned.
